snippet: Investigators can legally confiscate a cellphone and review video only after obtaining a court order, which is not required if the owner consents, a law professor said.
abstract: Cellphone videos shot by dozens of bystanders during recent incident in which Darrius H Kennedy was shot and killed by New York City police officers near Times Square have caught the attention of law enforcement officials; question has been raised of what rights the police have to witnesses' phone and whether the officers make it clear that bystanders are not legally obligated to turn over their phones; phones can be legally confiscated and video reviewed only after a court order is obtained.

byline.original: By WENDY RUDERMAN and AARON EDWARDS

lead_paragraph: Investigators can legally confiscate a cellphone and review video only after obtaining a court order, which is not required if the owner consents, a law professor said.

headline.seo: The Police Sought Cellphone Video of Times Square Shooting
headline.main: Police Sought Cellphones for Video of Times Square Shooting
headline.print_headline: Police Sought Cellphones for Times Sq. Shooting Video
